summary: This is a forensic evidence report from the US Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General, detailing the collection, imaging, and analysis of computer hardware (desktops and hard drives) seized in August 2019. The report documents the chain of custody, technical specifications, and imaging results for evidence related to case 2019-010614.

persons.name: Lidsky
persons.context: Conducted imaging of hard drives removed from seized desktop computers at the CC lab on August 11, 2019.

persons.name: Leonard
persons.context: Name appears in a document title ('Leonard Notes.docx') listed as a case attachment.

persons.name: ITS Canabal
persons.context: Listed as the 'Collection From' staff member for evidence collected on August 11, 2019.

events.title: Evidence Seizure and Initial Imaging
events.description: Multiple desktop computers and hard drives were seized. Forensic examiner Lidsky began imaging hard drives at the CC lab.

events.title: Case Opened for Forensic Analysis
events.description: Case 2019-010614 was officially opened for forensic examination with a 7-day service level.

events.title: Continued Forensic Imaging
events.description: Additional forensic imaging of seized desktop computers was performed.

events.title: Additional Evidence Submission
events.description: Two additional desktop computers were submitted to the case, as noted in the case background.

events.title: Forensic Report Produced
events.description: This forensic evidence report was generated, summarizing the examination results.

1401 S Clark St. Suite 900, Arlington, VA 22202 (US Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General)
keyFacts: The document is a forensic evidence report for DOJ OIG case 2019-010614, involving the seizure and analysis of computer hardware.
Evidence includes four HP EliteDesk 800 desktops and four associated hard drives (Seagate and Hitachi brands), seized on or around August 11, 2019.
Forensic imaging was performed by an examiner named Lidsky using Tableau write blockers, with detailed hash values (MD5, SHA1) recorded for verification.
The case was handled by the Cyber Investigations offices in both New York and Washington, D.C., indicating a multi-jurisdictional digital investigation.
The report confirms forensic procedures were followed and the examination was deemed 'forensically sound' by technical review.
